description:
In Nextoid! you play a nano-robot that has been injected into the bloodstream of sick humans and must eliminate all signs of infection from their arteries. You are armed with 5 anti-atherosclerosis projectiles and must clear a total of 27 arterial blockages. Power-ups are available to aid your progress and you will also encounter viruses, out to hinder you.

Nextoid! is a homage to the 80's arcade classic Arkanoid. It is a bat-and-ball game, designed to test your reflexes. You must move your bat along a horizontal plain at the bottom of the screen and deflect a bouncing ball onto the coloured blocks above, destroying them one by one until the level is cleared. If you miss the ball, your ship will be destroyed and you lose a life. Some blocks will release collectible power-ups, which may or may not be useful. Helpful power-ups include giving your bat additional laser fire, extending it, slowing down the ball, etc. Unhelpful power-ups include shrinking the bat, speeding-up the ball etc. You will also be hindered by 'viruses' that aim to get in the way of the ball's path and deflect it back at you.
title: Nextoid!

description:
Dungeonette is a homage to 1980s dungeon crawlers, in particular, the ZX Spectrum / BBC Micro title Atic Atac. The game is viewed from a bird's-eye view perspective, with a 4-way directional movement and a single button firing control.

You play a knight who must fight through a labyrinth of 3 levels (totalling 91 rooms) in order to slay the 'Evil Reaper'. Many of the rooms contain at least one enemy, which you must defeat by throwing an unlimited supply of projectiles, including knives and axes, with each enemy requiring multiple hits. The enemies themselves have no projectile weapons and can only damage you by chasing and touching you.

Throughout the game, items can be collected. These include: armour (temporary shield), gold and green keys (to unlock room doors or level exits respectively), food (to replenish damage sustained by enemies or traps such as floor spikes), boots (to create path) and gold coins (to boost your score).

The game ends when you enter the Reaper's room and hit him multiple times whilst avoiding being touched.
title: Dungeonette

description:
In DeltaStar: Earth Defence the player gets to pilot the top-secret starfighter 'Project DeltaStar' and fight the invading insect-like aliens. This game is a derivative of classic 80's single-screen vertical shooters such as Galaxians. The gameplay is set in a single screen, with your ship's movement limited to a fixed horizontal plane at the bottom of the screen. The banks of enemies above you move in a grouped horizontal formation, firing down at you. Some ships will split from the flock and dive bomb you whilst firing at ever closer range, forcing you to avoid a collision as well as the bullets.

The game is divided into 'systems', with each containing several attack waves, including dodging asteroids and an end of level boss. Each wave must be cleared before the next appears. You start with a basic single shot weapon, which can be upgraded to more powerful weapons such as double shot, fireballs, and deflector shield, by collecting the descending power-up tokens. Shooting at the token changes which weapon will be collected.

The game ends when you have cleared all 9 systems.
title: DeltaStar: Earth Defence

sample_screenshots.caption: An early introduction to switches, traps and roaming enemies.
Two deadly snakes. Good job you're equipped with a pistol and a whip!

description:
This compilation contains three games on one SD card:

  • DeltaStar: Earth Defence: a shoot 'em up in the style of Galaga, Phoenix and Space Invaders
  • Dungeonette: an arcade adventure type game in the style of the Spectrum game Atic Atac. Collect keys and treasure and escape the dungeons.
  • Montana Mike: a platform game - collect keys, treasure, solve puzzles and escape that dreadful maze.
title: Gold Compilation

description:
In Angry Bloaters you play as Old John, who must destroy the deadly Bloaters with his infinite supply of bombs.

This game is a homage of the 1983 Hudson Soft title Eric and the Floaters with additional power-ups more commonly found in later versions of the game.

To complete each stage, all enemies must be destroyed by blowing them up with a timed bomb. The Bloaters tend to roam the maze but will change colour from green to red at certain intervals and pursue you around the maze. You can either try to destroy them for additional points or hide until they return to their more placid state. Like the original version, your bombs cannot trap either yourself or the enemies. You can blow up walls to collect treasure (to boost score) and gain power-ups such as shoes (to increase speed) and bombs with extra range.

On every fourth stage, auto-bombing is enabled, forcing you to keep moving or risk being blown up where you stand. On some stages, you can wrap around to the other side of the screen,Pac-Man-style.

sample_screenshots.caption: Blowing up a wall tile has revealed some treasure.
A mistimed bomb exploding before the 'Bloater' was in range.

title: Angry Bloaters

description: Bubblegum Bros. is a two-player single-screen platform game whereby you must fire bubblegum bubbles to destroy a barrage of monsters that enter the playing area from the top of the screen. You can use your jet pack to jump around the platforms. Power-ups such as limited invincibility, firebomb bubbles, and enemy freezing can be collected to help destroy enemies as well to attain a high score. A level warp must be collected to advance to the next screen. There are 8 themed stages (Candy Land, Fearful Forest etc.) which contain 8 levels/screens each. A boss must be defeated on screen 8 of each stage to advance to the next.
title: Bubblegum Bros.

description: Dweebs Drop is a match-three arcade puzzle game, whereby coloured 'Dweebs' fall from the top of the screen and must be matched with three or more of the same colour in order to clear that line. Matching four in a square pattern will create a 'super Dweeb' which will gain extra points when destroyed by a fifth. Hitting black a black Dweeb will add a line to your opponent and hitting a coloured egg will destroy clear everything of that colour. There are three game modes - 1P against Schnoodle the dog (CPU), 2P, and alternatively playing as gems instead of Dweebs. The game has only one screen and one level, so once you have defeated an opponent, the game carries on for you until lose your own life.
title: Dweebs Drop

description:
In Orb Run, you play Rotox, a little robot who needs to move around a grid avoiding the holes into the void, whilst leaving behind a trail of orb seeds. Two holes will appear horizontally and vertically either side of the orb seed and walking into a hole will end the game. Going back to an orb seed, however, will generate four power orbs and fill in the void holes. Collecting power orbs will increase your score but if you get stuck, you must spend four of those points to remove the surrounding void. The game is designed to be unwinnable and to challenge yourself at a high score.

The author cites the inspiration for this game to be the 1982 magazine type-in game Magic Dollar Seeds for the Sinclair ZX81 and it was submitted to the 2018 ToeJam competition.

sample_screenshots.caption: Collecting the left orb creates new voids and sows another seed.
Moving one grid place makes voids appear.

title: Orb Run

description:
Crowley: World Tour is an unofficial port of Tetris, presented by the cartoon character Crowley. Your task is to fit falling tetrominoes together to form a complete line which will then destroy that line. If complete lines are not formed, the tetromino pieces will stack up and reach the top of the playing area, ending the game.

This version features three game modes (world tour, endless, and challenge). In World Tour, the player must navigate 20 consecutive levels with a city-themed background, as opposed to Endless mode which allows you to choose your start level and isn't location themed. In challenge mode, solid blocks are placed in the playing area and the player must navigate around them and try to destroy them by including them in a complete tetromino line.

sample_screenshots.caption: Challenge mode - level 2. Destroy the solid blocks by including them in a complete tetromino line

title: Crowley: World Tour

description:
Farmer Sam the dog has discovered that the hayloft trap door is open and his hay bales are bouncing everywhere. He must search the barn to find the key to relock the trap door whilst avoiding being hit by his hay bales or drowning in pools of water.

Farmer Sam's Dog Day is an 80's style, 2D fixed-screen platformer, whereby the player must reach the exit of each screen by traversing the platforms whilst avoiding bales of hay falling from the top of the screen. On some levels, the player must climb ladders or jump down ledges, whilst on others, the player just needs to jump across platforms from one side to the other. The player must reach each screen exit before the countdown timer expires. There are 24 built-in screens and the developer provides a link to an on-line level painter so that the player can create, download, and play their own screens.
title: Farmer Sam's Dog Day

description:
Guide Professor Rickamex of the Miskatonic University to find an ancient scroll has been buried on a remote island off the coast of New England. The scroll is said to be a map of a world inside our Earth - the Hollow Earth Hypothesis.

This game is a 2D platform adventure, consisting of 80 screens. There are 20 items scattered around the island to collect and each one has a special use. The island comprises of 3 ground levels, caves, and a subterranean lake. There are also 99 gold coins available to collect, for which an extra life will be awarded upon gathering 40. There are also various animal enemies that need to be avoided and bridges and gates to unlock.
title: The Hollow Earth Hypothesis

description:
The intrepid explorer 'Baggers' is searching for valuable planetary assets but he, unfortunately, keeps crash-landing onto the planets he is visiting. Help him to rebuild his rocket so he can continue his journey.

Baggers in Space is a 2D platform adventure game that is heavily influenced by the 1983 game Jetpac as well as elements from the 1984 game H.E.R.O. You must fly around on your jetpack, collecting three parts of your rocket, whilst defending yourself from enemies with your laser. Once the rocket is reassembled, you are then given dynamite, which you must use to open up the caverns below and to blast through walls in order to search for the rocket's three fuel cells. Some inaccessible areas can only be unlocked with a key. As well as a health meter, you also have an air meter which steadily declines as time progresses but both can be replenished by pick-ups underground. The quicker you finish the level, the more bonus points will be awarded. There are also idols to collect which grant you a bonus or power-up which is unique to that planet. There are 16 themed worlds to explore, each with their own inhabitants and traps.

sample_screenshots.caption: That golden idol below will either give points, health, or special abilities. Idols tend to be surrounded by traps.
Keeping a safe distance before the explosive detonates.
Below Tootanky, searching for the fuel.
Taking out a hostile below the surface of planet 4, 'Arborianna'.

title: Baggers in Space

description: In Tyvarian you journey to the fabled crystal arenas of Lavey on a quest to collect the valuable resources. This is a maze/arena game where you have to collect all the crystals before the countdown timer runs out whilst avoiding contact with the enemies. Some enemies can be temporarily stunned with your laser, whilst others are impervious. Some enemies will chase you if you get too close. You can use your boost to move around the screen quicker but at the cost of some control, so use wisely. There are eight different ship designs to choose from. The best way to play the game is to figure out the pattern of the enemies and plot the most efficient route, as bonus points are awarded depending on how quickly you complete each arena.

sample_screenshots.caption: Grid 02-02. These enemies can't fire at you but will chase you if you get too close.
Grid 01-02. Same as before but now a more complex pattern.
Grid 01-01. Collect all the crystals whilst avoiding the enemies or their projectiles. These enemies can be stunned with your laser for a short time.
Grid 01-03. A good level to use your boost to finish quicker and gain a bigger score bonus. Don't forget to stun the enemies as well.

title: Tyvarian

description: Warhawk is an enhanced remake of the 1986 multi-platform title Warhawk published by Firebird. Like the original, it is a scrolling vertical shooter, whereby you fight waves of enemy ships whilst dodging indestructible asteroids. Bonus points are rewarded at the end of the level for destroying all parts of the ground base. This version also retains the depleting damage meter and power-ups that increase speed and firepower. Unlike the original, there are now end-of-level mini-bosses to defeat, additional enemy types and patterns, and 20 levels instead of 10. The graphics have also been upgraded to the Next's resolution and colour palette.

sample_screenshots.caption: One of the larger enemy ships.

title: Warhawk

description:
Scramble is an unofficial port of the classic Konami side-scrolling arcade shooter Scramble, whereby the developers' stated aim was to replicate the original as closely as possible. The ZX Spectrum Next version includes 4 different screen resolutions, one of which replicates the original vertical view of the arcade version.

You pilot a futuristic jet through six terrains and must avoid or destroy missiles and UFO's whilst shooting fuel tanks to replenish your dwindling fuel. Your ship is equipped with a forward-firing gun and unlimited bombs. Finally, you must infiltrate an enemy base and destroy it.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 3. Avoid the indestructible fireballs whilst bombing ground targets.
Starting the game. Bombe the missiles before they launch shoot them mid-air.
Level 2. Shoot the UFO's whilst remembering to bomb any fuel tanks before your fuel runs out.

title: Scramble

description: 4k Race Next is an enhanced version of the 2005 ZX Spectrum game 4k Race Refueled, developed by the same team, with updated graphics and a faster frame rate. As before, it is a Pole Position style 2D behind-view racing game whereby you must avoid contact with oncoming computer opponents and the edge of the track. There are 7 checkpoints to reach before the timer runs out. The track is different for each game.
title: 4k Race Next

description: In Bikers you race with your motorcycle against the clock to reach the next stage, whilst battling wheel-to-wheel with your opponents. There are five courses set on five continents. The gameplay is fast and inspired by titles like Hang-On. There are multiple difficulty levels.
title: Bikers

description:
Nextipede is a version of the arcade classic Centipede. It was the first game to be released on the Spectrum Next and has been included on the Next's distribution SD card ever since. It was designed to test the Next's compatibility with the Timex 8x1 enhanced colour attribute mode.

All the elements from the arcade version are recreated; you control a 'bug buster' that must destroy a centipede moving down the screen towards you through a field of mushrooms. Each segment of the centipede becomes a mushroom when shot and the centipede splits into two pieces at that point. Spiders. snakes and fleas are also trying to impede you and must be avoided or shot.

sample_screenshots.caption: Avoid spiders that jump on you, fleas that create mushrooms and snakes.

title: Nextipede

description:
After shutting down the underground bases on the planet Aeon of the crime boss Lady Mandrill, famed troubleshooter Grelox tracks her down to Colony 7.

Grelox: Colony 7 is the fourth game set in the Grelox universe and a direct sequel to the third game, Grelox. Unlike the previous platform and shooting games, this is described as a digital comic, which is designed more like a graphical text adventure. However, rather than typing a verb-noun command into a text parser, you are presented with a HUD which shows the available actions for that screen and you just press the corresponding letter key. The keys are N (North), S (south), E (east), W (West), L (Look), I (Item) and T (Talk). Actions will be greyed out if unavailable for that location.

The gameplay involves you travelling around the map and conversing with the characters in each location. They all require you do them a fetch them items in exchange for information that will lead you to Lady Mandrill. The dialogue style is comedic and mildly adult in places.

sample_screenshots.caption: Heading East to the shanty towns to get more information.
Another location, another guard that needs to be bribed.
This trader is bound to have some interesting items. But what will they want in return?

title: Grelox: Colony 7

description:
Receiving a distress signal from the Xicus System, Grelox has to gather vegetation from various worlds to help create a vaccine for a deadly contagion.

Grelox: Contagion is the fifth game set in the Grelox universe. This is a puzzle platform game. Each of the 100 levels is presented as a single screen, whereby you must collect all the flowers on that screen before advancing to the next level. You must plan your route around the screen as it is easy to get trapped and you can't reverse your steps. There are stone blocks that can either be pushed out of the way (as long there are no blocks on either side or below), or broken up via your 'plasma slicer', although you can only destroy the stone below you and this action can't be undone. There are also spiked blocks that will kill you if touched. Some levels require switches to be activated to open doors and close floor traps. The enemies can kill you with one touch and can't be destroyed themselves. You are given one life and no energy bar.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level select screen. Completed levels can be skipped thanks to the auto-save.
The start of level 3. As before, taking time to plan a route may be wise.
The start of level 1. Plan the route to each flower in advance if you can, or you could trap yourself.
Starting level 2. Which way to go?

title: Grelox: Contagion

description:
Q*Bee lives in Beeville and has entered a strange portal at the edge of the forest. He's now trapped in a world of blocks and creatures trying to kill him and now needs your help to get him back home.

Q*Bee! is a Q*Bert variant. You must keep jumping on the cubes to change them to the target colour. Every block in the pyramid must be changed in order to complete the level. Each level requires a different strategy, for example, you may have to jump on the cubes twice to change them to the desired colour or the block may revert back to its original colour if you jump on it a second time. The enemies will kill you with one touch but you can avoid them either by jumping on the warp discs (which returns you back to the top of the screen) or by using a limited supply of smart bombs which kills all enemies on screen. Some enemies will follow their own pattern whereas others will chase after you. Some enemies will reverse the changes you've made, although you will be awarded points if you chase and catch them. There are 36 stages divided into 9 Levels of 4 rounds each.

sample_screenshots.caption: Using the side discs to warp back to the top.
By level 2, the blocks need to be jumped on twice to change them to the required colour.
You can use a smart bomb to destroy enemies if are about to catch you.
Some of the enemies follow their own pattern, whereas others will actively chase you.

title: Q*Bee!

description:
Ranble is a take on the classic Scramble-style arcade game. It has a constantly changing random terrain (hence the name 'Ran(dom)-(scram)ble'), covered in a variety of buildings, fuel tanks and missiles. As the game progresses, the terrain graphics change to indicate a new level - each level also has a variety of attacking aliens (from horizontal missile attacks, zig-zagging saucers and bouncing aliens) and the frequency of various elements on the terrain change (i.e. less fuel tanks, more missiles, etc) to make it harder.

The program is free, and its code and graphics can be edited/modified or just used to learn from.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 3 - Blue, with less fuel and introduces lethal bouncing alien attackers
New High Score name input using a classic arcade grid system
Opening title screen and scoring table
Level 1 - The easiest in a pretty pink/purple, plenty of fuel, gently zig-zagging UFO's
Updated high score table cycles colours to celebrate!

title: Ranble

description:
Photographs of world leaders have been torn to pieces. Can you put them back together?

Foreign Cabinet is a sliding tile-matching game, inspired by the 1986 title Split Personalities, also known as Splitting Images.

You are given a complete picture on the right side of the screen and must move the jumbled up pieces that emerge from the chute to match it. All the pictures are of well known recent political leaders. You start with a blank play area and must bring new pieces into play. They will continue to slide across the area until they hit another piece, so you must push other blocks in their path to stop them where you want them. There are doors along the edge of the play area where you can eject pieces (deliberately or accidentally) and repellents which will send the tile back from where it came from. Not all tiles are related to the picture (rockets, diamonds, bombs, etc. ) and these items can be matched for bonus points or ejected. The bomb will explode and you will lose a life if not ejected quickly or doused with a water tile if available. Each puzzle must be completed within a set time limit and you are given three lives.

sample_screenshots.caption: Puzzle two - British Prime Minister (2016-2019), Theresa May.
The first picture - North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un.

title: Foreign Cabinet

description:
Help Digger McDigface navigate the ancient caverns of Myclops and find the lost golden idol.

Shpeed is a single screen maze-based collecting game, loosely based on the 1983 PC booter game Digger. The aim of the game is to use your digger to plough through the dirt of the caverns, collecting treasures such as gems, flowers etc., whilst avoiding the monsters that guard them. The enemies can only move within the cleared areas, for which you have to be careful not to clear a path to you.

Unlike Digger (and more like Boulder Dash), this remake removes the ability to use weapons to defend yourself and you must rely on either avoidance or clearing dirt under an object (such as a boulder) that can be used to crush enemies if they are directly below you. However, unlike Boulder Dash (and similar games), you can't indefinitely stay underneath a boulder (or other gravity affected object) until you move, and you will be killed by it yourself if you don't move straight away. You also can't push an object into the path of an enemy. This remake also introduces additional features as the levels progress, such as doors to unlock, force fields, booby traps and tunnels.

A level is cleared once all items on the screen are collected. There are 100 levels for you to navigate, with the ultimate goal to hunt down the 'golden idol'. You are given three lives per game and can restart from where you died.

sample_screenshots.caption: Enemies can be confined to their own area but you will often have to risk releasing them in order to reach the collectable flowers.
This level has multiple paths to take via the tunnels. Also, the rocks are now designed to trap you if don't move fast enough.
Closed doors need to be opened by pressing the control button. Later levels introduce keys to hunt for.
Clearing dirt under a boulder makes it drop. I just managed to move out the way.
Some levels have instant booby traps. If you don't move immediately, you'll lose a life.

title: Shpeed
